thread.title: City: Soda tax brought in $5.7 million in January, more than double expectations
thread.title_full: City: Soda tax brought in $5.7 million in January, more than double expectations

author: Julia Terruso
title: City: Soda tax brought in $5.7 million in January, more than double expectations
text:
City: Soda tax brought in $5.7 million in January, more than double expectations   4:56 PM EST 269 Share 
Julia Terruso covers City Hall. More by Julia Terruso Arrow icon 
revenue department projections, but less than the city needs in coming months to reach its stated goal, officials said Thursday. 
of early childhood education in the city. 
“Ax the Bev Tax” campaign, amid complaints from some beverage sellers of sales losses as high as 30 to 50 percent. 
’t get you there." 
The Budget Office’s projection of $2.3 million was intentionally conservative because this is a new tax, and it was difficult to determine the extent, if any, of issues that taxpayers would have in filing for the first month,” city spokesman Mike Dunn said. “… It is ironic that the industry, which has been saying for a year that we wouldn’t be able to fund the programs, is now accusing us of being too financially responsible.” 
avoid the tax to ultimately return. In doing its calculations, the administration assumed a 27 percent drop in beverage sales in the city as a result of the tax. 
much higher losses in the first two months of the tax and say layoffs are expected . 
I think my estimates are right on," he said. "There’s no way of knowing the layoff number but 280, 300 jobs will be gone one way or the other. If a person quits or goes on unemployment, or I lay them off, the jobs will be gone.” 
We haven’t seen that much of an impact,” said Melissa Bova, vice president of government affairs for the Pennsylvania Restaurant and Lodging Association. “When people go out, they’re going to get the soda no matter what — the problem is the cost of buying the product has gone up so they’re trying to find a way to not pass on the entire cost to the customer.” 
has been on fast-food chains increasing their prices to account for free refills.
